content.question: Assume that <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>50.0</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>mL</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> of <math alttext="1.0 molar N a C l aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="1.0 molar A g N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> were combined. According to the balanced equation, if <math alttext="50 .0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>50.0</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>mL</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> of <math alttext="2.0 molar N a C l aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>50.0</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>mL</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> of <math alttext="1.0 molar A g N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> were combined, the amount of precipitate formed would

choices.label: double, because all of the coefficients are 1
double, because the amount of one of the reactants was doubled
not change, because all of the coefficients are 1

not change, because the amount of <math alttext="A g N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> did not change

content.answer: not change, because the amount of <math alttext="A g N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> did not change

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
